message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Standard translations all use "virtue" for 德 — reconsider?">
New data for the 德 discussion. The passage 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼 (Dao De Jing Ch. 38) has well-established standard English translations:

**D.C. Lau**: "When the way was lost there was virtue; when virtue was lost there was benevolence; when benevolence was lost there was rectitude; when rectitude was lost there were the rites."

**Wing-tsit Chan**: "When the Way is lost, only then do we have virtue; when virtue is lost, only then do we have humanity; when humanity is lost, only then do we have righteousness; when righteousness is lost, only then do we have propriety."

**James Legge**: "When the Tao was lost, its attributes appeared; when its attributes were lost, benevolence appeared; when benevolence was lost, righteousness appeared; when righteousness was lost, the proprieties appeared."

Every major translator uses "virtue" for 德 in this passage. Our decision was "(constitutive) character" instead.

Given this data — does this change your view? Should we:
A) Keep "(constitutive) character" — our reasoned departure from tradition, acknowledged in TN
B) Use the standard "virtue" for the Laozi block quote specifically (since it IS a quotation of a classical text), then switch to "(constitutive) character" when the author begins their own analysis
C) Something else?

Brief response with your recommendation.
</teammate-message>

input.summary: Option B — virtue in quote, character in analysis
input.content:
**Option B.** This is the right answer for a precise reason:

The author explicitly states the 道德仁义礼 passage is "并非对《老子》的解释" -- it is NOT an interpretation of Laozi. The Laozi quotation is a *source text* that the author then *re-analyzes* in their own framework. These are two different speech acts: quoting and analyzing.

The block quote is Laozi's words. Use "virtue" -- it is the established rendering, the reader recognizes it, and we are not the ones translating the Dao De Jing. The moment the author begins their own analysis ("然而，礼事实上是从现象所总结出来的..."), switch to "(constitutive) character." A brief TN at the transition: "The author now departs from the traditional reading. Where 德 in the Laozi quotation is rendered as 'virtue' following standard convention, the author's own analysis uses '(constitutive) character' to reflect their constructivist reinterpretation of 德 as the defining properties abstracted from phenomena, not moral excellence."

This actually *strengthens* the philosophical experiment. The reader first sees the familiar "virtue" in the classical text, then watches the author dismantle and reconstruct it as "character." The terminological shift *enacts* the conceptual shift -- the reader experiences the inversion in real time through the change in vocabulary. Option A would hide this by using the same word throughout, flattening the very distinction the passage is trying to make visible.
